Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Towards Dependable Self-Powered Things for the IoT

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scaling the Internet of Things (IoT) to billions and possibly trillions of "things" requires transformative advances in the science, technology, and engineering of cyber-physical systems (CPS), with none more pressing or challenging than the power problem. Consider that if every device in a 1 trillion IoT network had a battery that lasted for a full five years, over 500 million batteries would need to be changed every day. Clearly, a battery-powered IoT is not feasible at this scale due to both human resource logistics and environmental concerns. There is a need for a batteryless approach that dependably meets functionality requirements using energy harvested from the physical world. This project brings together experts in materials, devices, circuits, and systems to pursue a holistic approach to self-powered wireless devices deployed in real-world environments and IoT systems and applications. In addition, educational and outreach activities will help develop the workforce for this relatively new field with the holistic, materials-to-systems perspective that will be necessary to lead innovation in this space.

A critical challenge that this project addresses is that both optimal device operation and energy harvester efficiency are heavily dependent on physical world dynamics, and thus, self-powered devices that are statically configured or that just respond to instantaneous conditions are unlikely to provide the dependability required for many IoT systems and applications. To address this fundamental and critically enabling challenge, data collections will be performed to study the physical world dynamics that impact device operation and harvester efficiency, such as ambient conditions, electromagnetic interference, and human behavior. This scientific study will lead to the development of dynamic models that will, in turn, be used to develop algorithms to dynamically configure devices and harvesters based not only on past and current conditions but also on predictions of future conditions. These algorithms will then be used to dynamically configure technological innovations in ultra-low power device operation and ultra-high efficiency energy harvesting to engineer and operate dependable self-powered things for the IoT.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scaling the Internet of Things (IoT) to billions and possibly trillions of “things” requires transformative advances in the science, technology, and engineering of cyber-physical systems (CPS), with none more pressing or challenging than the power problem. Consider that if every device in a 1 trillion thing IoT had a battery that lasted for a full five years, over 500 million batteries would need to be changed every day. A battery-powered IoT is simply not feasible at this scale due to both human resource logistics and environmental concerns, so self-powered operation is transformative and necessary for broad-based wireless interconnectivity. However, both optimal node operation and energy harvester efficiency are heavily dependent on physical world dynamics, and self-powered devices that are statically configured or that just respond to instantaneous conditions are unlikely to provide the dependability required for many IoT systems and applications.

This project explored this fundamental and critically enabling challenge. Data collections were performed to study the physical world dynamics that impact node operation and harvester efficiency, including ambient conditions and human behavior. This in turn enabled the development of dynamics models that were used to develop algorithms to dynamically configure nodes and harvesters based not only on past and current conditions but also on predictions of future conditions. These algorithms were developed in conjunction with technological innovations in ultra-low power circuits and ultra-high efficiency energy harvesters to engineer and operate dependable self-powered things for the IoT. This included several evolutions of designs for highly efficient and flexible energy harvesting circuits for harvesting power from motion and vibration, including a novel maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithm and integration with other harvesting modalities. Piezoelectric materials for harvesting motion and vibration were also explored, including comparisons of lead-containing and lead-free piezoelectric materials.

Intellectual Merit: This project brought together experts in materials, devices, circuits, and systems to pursue a holistic approach to self-powered wireless devices deployed in real-world environments. The collected profiles of physical world dynamics in IoT-related deployments provided a critical scientific foundation for the models and algorithms that drive the technology development and engineering of the self-powered wireless IoT. These system-level profiles informed the design and runtime control of configurable materials, devices, and circuits to maximize harvesting and operational efficiencies and to account for not only the past and present physical world conditions but also predictions of the future to provide dependable self-powered things for the IoT.

Broader Impact: A vision of one trillion connected things has moved from the dream of futurists to the goals of researchers, industries, and governments world-wide. This project provided a significant fundamental step in making devices not only self-powered – which is currently fraught with operational interruptions – but also dependable for a wide range of IoT applications. Another significant impact of this project was the education of students in this relatively new field with the holistic, materials-to-systems (and back again) perspective that will be necessary to lead innovation in this space.
